text: Thank you so much, Robin Lakshmi.
It's always an honor and a joy to be with you.
I'm dedicating this piece today to the enslaved laborers
and the almost-free laborers who built
the University of Virginia and so many other physical
and social structures within our society
and didn't receive proper recognition
or renumeration for doing so.
Personal reference and dedication
to my own ancestors, who were also builders
of the University of Virginia.
This piece was inspired by my discovery of an ancestor
by the name John Rubin Barber who
was documented as a 17- or 18-year-old "free"
colored man that labored as a waiter in Hotel A and Hotel F,
which were dormitories at the University of Virginia in 1860.
So, he was a free working man, so to speak,
but the question for us seven generations later --
was he and are we still waiting on freedom at work,
so the title of this piece is "Almost Free."
Like leaping into a mirror, traveling
to see her grandmothers along trails
that blaze with beguiled smiles and knowing gaze, almost free.
Her thirst was quenched by the waiter who served life
through seven mothers' favor from waiting on three school
boys and men, collecting pennies and waiting men on his family's
true freedom.
Almost free to match his papers and pennies
to be freed of terror and inequity, the shackles
of low expectation, stacked decks, and bruised egos,
patrons disappearing acts from the pages of history.
Almost free.
Where the dawn of righteousness what
make warriors of daughters and their daughters
and their daughters, seven generations of waiting
to be almost free.
Now Ethel married the son of a freeman
from Niagara's movements and named their son
Freeman and their daughter Norma,
like the standard bearer she was, to her daughters
and granddaughters and great granddaughters
so were the exceptions that follow
the rules by breaking the molds cast by their schools.
Almost free.
Business owners, doctors, teachers
with perfect penmanship, diction, and grammar.
Masters of discourse, poise, and mediation.
Caps and gowns flow generation over generation.
Never the first, always the first,
nevertheless, never the last.
Maybe the only refuse to be lonely,
stacking degrees and university IDs like trading cards
and passports to safe havens when weary of racial battle
fatigue from being sidelined in the major league, almost free.
From the fight for freedom claimed in fierce pride,
heads held high as daughters, who take ownership of homes
their mothers and fathers built and lived there
with the entitled peace and peace of mind and spirit.
Almost free to speak, to think, to labor freely and abundantly,
and dine on the fruits at the head table
where liberation was served to enable brothers and sisters
and cousins whose patience had grown thin waiting for days
when their long-lost birthright would be born again.
Almost free.
To be bold, to dream big, and lift up
the average colored girl.
No pretense, no unicorns, no rainbows,
no tap shoes, only chuck's and pearls
and a cocktail of imagination served with a paper on brother
to float high above the burden of exceptionalism
and simply be almost free.
To embrace the mundane when needed
to sustain a piece of glory and dignity and care,
to selfishly exercise the freedom
to fail, with grace and humility that second chances hail almost
free.
Where the gallows are reserved for the soul-crushing horror
of four centuries of raping and pillaging
lands and hands breaking through serpentine walls with truth
that only holy boldness can bring when freedom
starts to ring almost free.
Where the guardrails now stand in Charlottesville's
sacred land on the shoulders of those
who grieve from the Nigerian woes of Evaline's
daughters and her babies' babies' babies
until they can wait no more as it only serves to fight
with all her might to free them of the chore of being
almost free.
So she carried in her bosom there a game.
Seventeen years old, free, colored girl,
beckoned by ancestors to return to her Mecca destined
to beat the odds by playing chess while they play checkers.
Seven generations of completion, and 360 degrees
of freedom, full circle.
Almost free.
Almost free.
Almost free.
Thank you.
